**USS _Indianapolis_ (CL/CA-35)** was a [_Portland_ -class](/wiki/Portland-
class_cruiser "Portland-class cruiser") [heavy cruiser](/wiki/Heavy_cruiser
"Heavy cruiser") of the [United States Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United
States Navy"), named for the city of [Indianapolis](/wiki/Indianapolis
"Indianapolis"), Indiana. The vessel served as the [flagship](/wiki/Flagship
"Flagship") for the commander of [Scouting Force 1](/wiki/Scouting_Fleet
"Scouting Fleet") for eight pre-war years, then as flagship for
[Admiral](/wiki/Admiral_\(United_States\) "Admiral \(United States\)")
[Raymond Spruance](/wiki/Raymond_A._Spruance "Raymond A. Spruance"), in 1943
and 1944, while he commanded the [Fifth Fleet](/wiki/United_States_Fifth_Fleet
"United States Fifth Fleet") in battles across the Central Pacific in World
War II.

In 1945, the sinking of _Indianapolis_ led to the greatest single loss of life
at sea, from a single ship, in the history of the US Navy. The ship had just
finished a high-speed trip to [United States Army Air Force
Base](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force_base "United States Air Force base") at
[Tinian](/wiki/Tinian "Tinian"), to deliver parts of the first atomic bomb
ever used in combat (the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States")'
[Little Boy](/wiki/Little_Boy "Little Boy") [atomic bomb](/wiki/Atomic_Bomb
"Atomic Bomb")), and was on training duty. At 0015 on 30 July 1945 the ship
was torpedoed by the [Imperial Japanese Navy](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy
"Imperial Japanese Navy") submarine [_I-58_](/wiki/Japanese_submarine_I-58
"Japanese submarine I-58"). The ship, on her way to the Philippines, sank in
12 minutes. Of 1,196 crewmen aboard, approximately 300 went down with the
ship. The remaining 900 faced [exposure](/wiki/Hypothermia "Hypothermia"),
[dehydration](/wiki/Dehydration "Dehydration"), [saltwater
poisoning](/wiki/Hypernatremia "Hypernatremia"), and [shark
attacks](/wiki/Shark_attack "Shark attack") while floating with few lifeboats
and almost no food or water. The Navy learned of the sinking when survivors
were spotted four days later by the crew of a [PV-1
Ventura](/wiki/PV-1_Ventura "PV-1 Ventura") on routine patrol. Only 317
survived.

On 19 August 2017, a search team financed by [Paul Allen](/wiki/Paul_Allen
"Paul Allen") located the wreckage of the sunken cruiser in the [Philippine
Sea](/wiki/Philippine_Sea "Philippine Sea") lying at a depth of approximately
18,000 ft (5,500 m).[4]

##
Construction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Construction")]

Main article: [Portland-class cruiser](/wiki/Portland-class_cruiser "Portland-
class cruiser")

_Indianapolis_ was the second of two ships in the _Portland_ class; the third
class of "treaty cruisers" constructed by the [United States
Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy") following the [Washington
Naval Treaty](/wiki/Washington_Naval_Treaty "Washington Naval Treaty") of
1922, following the two vessels of the [_Pensacola_ class](/wiki/Pensacola-
class_cruiser "Pensacola-class cruiser"), ordered in 1926, and the six of the
[_Northampton_ class](/wiki/Northampton-class_cruiser "Northampton-class
cruiser"), ordered in 1927.[5] Ordered for the US Navy in fiscal year 1930.
_Indianapolis_ was originally designated as a [light
cruiser](/wiki/Light_cruiser "Light cruiser"), because of her thin armor, and
given the [hull classification symbol](/wiki/Hull_classification_symbol "Hull
classification symbol") CL-35. She was reclassified a [heavy
cruiser](/wiki/Heavy_cruiser "Heavy cruiser"), because of her 8-inch (203 mm)
guns, with the symbol CA-35 on 1 July 1931, in accordance with the [London
Naval Treaty](/wiki/London_Naval_Treaty "London Naval Treaty").[6]

As built, the _Portland_ -class cruisers were designed for a [standard
displacement](/wiki/Standard_displacement "Standard displacement") of 10,258
[long tons](/wiki/Long_ton "Long ton") (10,423 [t](/wiki/Tonne "Tonne")), and
a [full-load displacement](/wiki/Full-load_displacement "Full-load
displacement") of 12,755 long tons (12,960 t).[7] However, when completed, she
did not reach this weight, displacing 9,950 long tons (10,110 t).[8] The ship
had two distinctive raked funnels, a tripod [foremast](/wiki/Foremast
"Foremast"), and a small tower and pole mast aft. In 1943, light tripods were
added forward of the second funnel on each ship, and a prominent [Naval
director](/wiki/Naval_director "Naval director") was installed aft.[8]

The ship had four [propeller shafts](/wiki/Propeller_shaft_\(ship\) "Propeller
shaft \(ship\)") and four Parsons GT [geared turbines](/wiki/Geared_turbine
"Geared turbine") and eight [White-Forster boilers](/wiki/White-Forster_boiler
"White-Forster boiler"). The 107,000 [shp](/wiki/Horsepower#Shaft_horsepower
"Horsepower") (80,000 kW) gave a design speed of 32.7 [kn](/wiki/Knot_\(unit\)
"Knot \(unit\)") (60.6 km/h; 37.6 mph). She was designed for a range of 10,000
[nmi](/wiki/Nautical_mile "Nautical mile") (19,000 km; 12,000 mi) at 15 kn (28
km/h; 17 mph).[8] She rolled badly until fitted with a [bilge
keel](/wiki/Bilge_keel "Bilge keel").[6]

The cruiser had nine [8-inch/55 caliber](/wiki/8%22/55_caliber_gun "8"/55
caliber gun") Mark 9 guns in three triple mounts, a
[superfiring](/wiki/Superfiring "Superfiring") pair fore and one aft. For
[anti-aircraft](/wiki/Anti-aircraft "Anti-aircraft") defense, she had eight
[5-inch/25 caliber guns](/wiki/5%22/25_caliber_gun "5"/25 caliber gun") and
two [QF 3 pounder Hotchkiss](/wiki/QF_3_pounder_Hotchkiss "QF 3 pounder
Hotchkiss") guns. In 1945, she received 24 [40 mm (1.57 in)
Bofors](/wiki/Bofors_40mm "Bofors 40mm") guns, arrayed in six quad mounts.
Both ships were upgraded with 19 [20 mm (0.79 in) Oerlikon
cannons](/wiki/Oerlikon_20_mm_cannon "Oerlikon 20 mm cannon").[3] No [torpedo
tubes](/wiki/Torpedo_tube "Torpedo tube") were fitted on her.[9]

The _Portland_ class originally had 1-inch (25 mm) armor for deck and side
protection, but in construction[6] they were given [belt
armor](/wiki/Belt_armor "Belt armor") between 5 in (127 mm) (around the
[magazines](/wiki/Magazine_\(artillery\) "Magazine \(artillery\)")) and 3.25
in (83 mm) in thickness.[9] Armor on the
[bulkheads](/wiki/Bulkhead_\(partition\) "Bulkhead \(partition\)") was between
2 in (51 mm) and 5.75 in (146 mm); that on the [deck](/wiki/Deck_\(ship\)
"Deck \(ship\)") was 2.5 in (64 mm), the [barbettes](/wiki/Barbette
"Barbette") 1.5 in (38 mm), the [gunhouses](/wiki/Gunhouse "Gunhouse") 2.5 in,
and the [conning tower](/wiki/Conning_tower "Conning tower") 1.25 in (32
mm).[8]

_Portland_ -class cruisers were outfitted as [fleet
flagships](/wiki/Fleet_flagship "Fleet flagship"), with space for a [flag
officer](/wiki/Flag_officer "Flag officer") and his staff. The class also had
two [aircraft catapult](/wiki/Aircraft_catapult "Aircraft catapult")
amidships.[8] They could carry four aircraft. The total crew varied, with a
regular designed complement of 807,[7] a wartime complement of 952, which
could increase to 1,229 when the cruiser was a fleet flagship.[8]

_Indianapolis_ was [laid down](/wiki/Keel_laying "Keel laying") by [New York
Shipbuilding Corporation](/wiki/New_York_Shipbuilding_Corporation "New York
Shipbuilding Corporation") on 31 March 1930.[8] The hull and machinery were
provided by the builder.[6] _Indianapolis_ was
[launched](/wiki/Ship_naming_and_launching "Ship naming and launching") on 7
November 1931, and [commissioned](/wiki/Ship_commissioning "Ship
commissioning") on 15 November 1932.[8] She was the second ship named for
Indianapolis, following the [cargo ship of the same
name](/wiki/USS_Indianapolis_\(ID-3865\) "USS Indianapolis \(ID-3865\)") in
1918. She was [sponsored](/wiki/Ship_sponsor "Ship sponsor") by Lucy Taggart,
daughter of former [Mayor of
Indianapolis](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Indianapolis "List of mayors of
Indianapolis") [Thomas Taggart](/wiki/Thomas_Taggart "Thomas Taggart").[10]

## Interwar
period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Interwar period")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_underway_in_1939.jpg/220px-
USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_underway_in_1939.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_underway_in_1939.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_underway_in_1939.jpg "Enlarge")

_Indianapolis_ in 1939

Under [Captain](/wiki/Captain_\(United_States_O-6\) "Captain \(United States
O-6\)") John M. Smeallie, _Indianapolis_ undertook her [shakedown
cruise](/wiki/Shakedown_cruise "Shakedown cruise") through the Atlantic and
into [Guantánamo Bay](/wiki/Guant%C3%A1namo_Bay "Guantánamo Bay"), until 23
February 1932. _Indianapolis_ then transited the [Panama
Canal](/wiki/Panama_Canal "Panama Canal") for training off the
[Chilean](/wiki/Chile "Chile") coast. After overhaul at the [Philadelphia Navy
Yard](/wiki/Philadelphia_Navy_Yard "Philadelphia Navy Yard"), she sailed to
[Maine](/wiki/Maine "Maine"), to embark
[President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") [Franklin Delano Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt "Franklin
Delano Roosevelt") at [Campobello Island](/wiki/Campobello_Island "Campobello
Island"), New Brunswick, on 1 July 1933.[10] Getting under way the same day,
_Indianapolis_ arrived at [Annapolis](/wiki/Annapolis "Annapolis"), Maryland,
on 3 July. She hosted six members of the
[Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States "Cabinet of the United States"),
along with Roosevelt, during its stay there. After disembarking Roosevelt, she
departed Annapolis, on 4 July, and steamed for Philadelphia Navy Yard.[11]

On 6 September, she embarked [Secretary of the
Navy](/wiki/Secretary_of_the_Navy "Secretary of the Navy") [Claude A.
Swanson](/wiki/Claude_A._Swanson "Claude A. Swanson"), for an inspection of
the Navy in the Pacific. _Indianapolis_ toured the Canal Zone, Hawaii, and
installations in [San Pedro](/wiki/San_Pedro,_Los_Angeles "San Pedro, Los
Angeles") and [San Diego](/wiki/San_Diego "San Diego"). Swanson disembarked on
27 October. On 1 November 1933, she became flagship of [Scouting
Force](/wiki/Scouting_Force "Scouting Force") 1, and maneuvered with the force
off [Long Beach, California](/wiki/Long_Beach,_California "Long Beach,
California"). She departed on 9 April 1934, and arrived at New York City, and
embarked Roosevelt, a second time, for a [naval review](/wiki/Naval_review
"Naval review"). She returned to Long Beach, on 9 November 1934, for more
training with the Scouting Force. She remained flagship of Scouting Force 1
until 1941. On 18 November 1936, she embarked Roosevelt, a third time, at
[Charleston, South Carolina](/wiki/Charleston,_South_Carolina "Charleston,
South Carolina"), and conducted a goodwill cruise to South America with him.
She visited [Rio de Janeiro, Brazil](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro,_Brazil "Rio de
Janeiro, Brazil"), [Buenos Aires, Argentina](/wiki/Buenos_Aires,_Argentina
"Buenos Aires, Argentina"), and [Montevideo,
Uruguay](/wiki/Montevideo,_Uruguay "Montevideo, Uruguay"), for state visits
before returning to Charleston, and disembarking Roosevelt's party on 15
December.[11] President Roosevelt underwent his [crossing the
line](/wiki/Line-crossing_ceremony "Line-crossing ceremony") ceremony on this
cruise on 26 November: an "intensive initiation lasting two days, but we have
all survived and are now full-fledged Shellbacks".[12]

## World War
II[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: World War II")]

On 7 December 1941, _Indianapolis_ was conducting a mock bombardment at
[Johnston Atoll](/wiki/Johnston_Atoll "Johnston Atoll"), during the [Japanese
attack on Pearl Harbor](/wiki/Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Japanese attack
on Pearl Harbor"). _Indianapolis_ was absorbed into [Task Force
12](/w/index.php?title=Task_Force_12&action=edit&redlink=1 "Task Force 12
\(page does not exist\)") and searched for the
[Japanese](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan") carriers responsible for
the attack, though the force did not locate them. She returned to [Pearl
Harbor](/wiki/Naval_Station_Pearl_Harbor "Naval Station Pearl Harbor") on 13
December, and joined [Task Force 11](/wiki/Task_Force_11 "Task Force 11").[11]

### New Guinea
campaign[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: New Guinea campaign")]

Main article: [New Guinea campaign](/wiki/New_Guinea_campaign "New Guinea
campaign")

With the task force, she steamed to the [South
Pacific](/wiki/South_West_Pacific_theatre_of_World_War_II "South West Pacific
theatre of World War II"), to 350 mi (560 km) south of [Rabaul](/wiki/Rabaul
"Rabaul"), [New Britain](/wiki/New_Britain "New Britain"), escorting the
[aircraft carrier](/wiki/Aircraft_carrier "Aircraft carrier")
[_Lexington_](/wiki/USS_Lexington_\(CV-2\) "USS Lexington \(CV-2\)"). Late in
the afternoon of 20 February 1942, the American ships were attacked by 18
Japanese aircraft. Of these, 16 were shot down by aircraft from _Lexington_
and the other two were destroyed by anti-aircraft fire from the ships.[11]

On 10 March, the task force, reinforced by another force centered on the
carrier [_Yorktown_](/wiki/USS_Yorktown_\(CV-5\) "USS Yorktown \(CV-5\)"),
attacked [Lae](/wiki/Lae "Lae") and [Salamaua](/wiki/Salamaua "Salamaua"), New
Guinea, where the Japanese were marshaling [amphibious
forces](/wiki/Amphibious_warfare "Amphibious warfare"). Attacking from the
south through the [Owen Stanley mountain
range](/wiki/Owen_Stanley_mountain_range "Owen Stanley mountain range"), the
US air forces surprised and inflicted heavy damage on Japanese warships and
transports, losing few aircraft. _Indianapolis_ returned to the [Mare Island
Naval Shipyard](/wiki/Mare_Island_Naval_Shipyard "Mare Island Naval Shipyard")
for a refit before escorting a convoy to Australia.[11]

### Aleutian Islands
campaign[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Aleutian Islands campaign")]

Main article: [Aleutian Islands campaign](/wiki/Aleutian_Islands_campaign
"Aleutian Islands campaign")

_Indianapolis_ then headed for the North Pacific to support American units in
the Battle of the Aleutian Islands. On 7 August, _Indianapolis_ and the task
force attacked [Kiska Island](/wiki/Kiska_Island "Kiska Island"), a Japanese
staging area. Although fog hindered observation, _Indianapolis_ and other
ships fired their main guns into the bay. [Floatplanes](/wiki/Floatplane
"Floatplane") from the cruisers reported Japanese ships sunk in the harbor and
damage to shore installations. After 15 minutes, Japanese shore batteries
returned fire before being destroyed by the ships' main guns. Japanese
submarines approaching the force were [depth-charged](/wiki/Depth_charge
"Depth charge") by American [destroyers](/wiki/Destroyer "Destroyer").
Japanese seaplanes made an ineffective bombing attack. In spite of a lack of
information on the Japanese forces, the operation was considered a success. US
forces later occupied [Adak Island](/wiki/Adak_Island "Adak Island"),
providing a naval base farther from the [Dutch Harbor](/wiki/Dutch_Harbor
"Dutch Harbor") on [Unalaska Island](/wiki/Unalaska_Island "Unalaska Island").

### 1943
operations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 1943 operations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_underway_at_sea%2C_in_1943-1944_%28NH_124466%29.jpg/220px-
USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_underway_at_sea%2C_in_1943-1944_%28NH_124466%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_underway_at_sea,_in_1943-1944_\(NH_124466\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_underway_at_sea,_in_1943-1944_\(NH_124466\).jpg
"Enlarge")

USS _Indianapolis_ (CA-35) underway at sea, in 1943-1944 (NH 124466)

In January 1943, _Indianapolis_ supported a landing and occupation on
[Amchitka](/wiki/Amchitka "Amchitka"), part of an
[Allied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") [island
hopping](/wiki/Leapfrogging_\(strategy\) "Leapfrogging \(strategy\)") strategy
in the Aleutian Islands.[11]

On the evening of 19 February, _Indianapolis_ led two destroyers on a patrol
southwest of [Attu Island](/wiki/Attu_Island "Attu Island"), searching for
Japanese ships trying to reinforce Kiska and Attu. She intercepted the
Japanese 3,100-long-ton (3,150 t) [cargo ship](/wiki/Cargo_ship "Cargo ship"),
[_Akagane Maru_](/w/index.php?title=Akagane_Maru&action=edit&redlink=1
"Akagane Maru \(page does not exist\)") laden with troops, munitions, and
supplies. The cargo ship tried to reply to the radio challenge but was shelled
by _Indianapolis_. _Akagane Maru_ exploded and sank with all hands. Through
mid-1943, _Indianapolis_ remained near the Aleutian Islands, escorting
American convoys and providing shore bombardments supporting [amphibious
assaults](/wiki/Amphibious_assault "Amphibious assault"). In May, the Allies
captured Attu, then turned on Kiska, thought to be the final Japanese holdout
in the Aleutians. Allied landings there began on 15 August, but the Japanese
had already abandoned the Aleutian Islands, unbeknownst to the Allies.[11]

After refitting at Mare Island, _Indianapolis_ moved to Hawaii as flagship of
[Vice Admiral](/wiki/Vice_admiral_\(United_States\) "Vice admiral \(United
States\)") [Raymond A. Spruance](/wiki/Raymond_A._Spruance "Raymond A.
Spruance"), commanding the [5th Fleet](/wiki/United_States_Fifth_Fleet "United
States Fifth Fleet"). She sortied from Pearl Harbor on 10 November, with the
main body of the [Southern Attack
Force](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Attack_Force&action=edit&redlink=1
"Southern Attack Force \(page does not exist\)") for [Operation
_Galvanic_](/wiki/Operation_Galvanic "Operation Galvanic"), the invasion of
the [Gilbert Islands](/wiki/Gilbert_Islands "Gilbert Islands"). On 19
November, _Indianapolis_ bombarded [Tarawa Atoll](/wiki/Tarawa_Atoll "Tarawa
Atoll"), and next day pounded [Makin](/wiki/Makin_\(islands\) "Makin
\(islands\)") (see _[Battle of Makin](/wiki/Battle_of_Makin "Battle of
Makin")_). The ship then returned to Tarawa, as fire-support for the landings.
Her guns shot down an enemy plane and shelled enemy strongpoints as landing
parties fought Japanese defenders in the [battle of
Tarawa](/wiki/Battle_of_Tarawa "Battle of Tarawa"). She continued this role
until the island was secure three days later. The conquest of the [Marshall
Islands](/wiki/Marshall_Islands "Marshall Islands") followed victory in the
Gilberts. _Indianapolis_ was again 5th Fleet flagship.

###
1944[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 1944")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_underway_in_1944_%28stbd%29.jpg/220px-
USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_underway_in_1944_%28stbd%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_underway_in_1944_\(stbd\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_underway_in_1944_\(stbd\).jpg
"Enlarge")

_Indianapolis_ in 1944 [dazzle camouflage](/wiki/Dazzle_camouflage "Dazzle
camouflage") pattern.

The cruiser met other ships of her task force at Tarawa, and on
[D-Day](/wiki/D-Day_\(military_term\) "D-Day \(military term\)") minus 1, 31
January 1944, she was one of the cruisers that bombarded the islands of
[Kwajalein Atoll](/wiki/Kwajalein_Atoll "Kwajalein Atoll"). The shelling
continued on D-Day, with _Indianapolis_ suppressing two enemy shore batteries.
Next day, she destroyed a blockhouse and other shore installations and
supported advancing troops with a [creeping barrage](/wiki/Creeping_barrage
"Creeping barrage"). The ship entered Kwajalein Lagoon, on 4 February, and
remained until resistance disappeared. (See _[Battle of
Kwajalein](/wiki/Battle_of_Kwajalein "Battle of Kwajalein")_.)

In March and April, _Indianapolis_ , still flagship of the 5th Fleet, attacked
the [Western Carolines](/wiki/Western_Carolines "Western Carolines"). Carrier
planes at the [Palau Islands](/wiki/Palau_Islands "Palau Islands") on 30–31
March, sank three destroyers, 17 freighters, five
[oilers](/wiki/Replenishment_oiler "Replenishment oiler") and damaged 17 other
ships. Airfields were bombed and surrounding water [mined](/wiki/Naval_mine
"Naval mine"). [Yap](/wiki/Yap "Yap") and [Ulithi](/wiki/Ulithi "Ulithi"),
were struck on 31 March, and [Woleai](/wiki/Woleai "Woleai"), on 1 April.
Japanese planes attacked but were driven off without damaging the American
ships. _Indianapolis_ shot down her second plane, a torpedo bomber, and the
Japanese lost 160 planes, including 46 on the ground. These attacks prevented
Japanese forces stationed in the Carolines from interfering with the US
landings on [New Guinea](/wiki/New_Guinea "New Guinea").

In June, the 5th Fleet was busy with the assault on the [Mariana
Islands](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana Islands"). Raids on
[Saipan](/wiki/Saipan "Saipan") began with carrier-based planes on 11 June,
followed by surface bombardment, in which _Indianapolis_ had a major role,
from 13 June. (See _[Battle of Saipan](/wiki/Battle_of_Saipan "Battle of
Saipan")_.) On D-Day, 15 June, ADM Spruance heard that
[battleships](/wiki/Battleship "Battleship"), carriers, cruisers, and
destroyers were headed south to relieve threatened garrisons in the Marianas.
Since amphibious operations at Saipan had to be protected, ADM Spruance could
not withdraw too far. Consequently, a fast carrier force was sent to meet this
threat while another force attacked Japanese air bases on [Iwo
Jima](/wiki/Iwo_Jima "Iwo Jima") and [Chichi Jima](/wiki/Chichi_Jima "Chichi
Jima"), in the [Bonin](/wiki/Bonin_Islands "Bonin Islands") and [Volcano
Islands](/wiki/Volcano_Islands "Volcano Islands"), bases for potential enemy
air attacks.

A combined US fleet fought the Japanese on 19 June, in the [Battle of the
Philippine Sea](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Philippine_Sea "Battle of the Philippine
Sea"). Japanese carrier planes, which planned to use the airfields of
[Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam") and [Tinian](/wiki/Tinian "Tinian"), to refuel and
rearm, were met by carrier planes and the guns of the Allied escorting ships.
That day, the US Navy destroyed a reported 426 Japanese planes while losing
29.[13] _Indianapolis_ shot down one torpedo plane. This day of aerial combat
became known as the "Marianas Turkey Shoot". With Japanese air opposition
wiped out, the US carrier planes sank
[_Hiyō_](/wiki/Japanese_aircraft_carrier_Hiy%C5%8D "Japanese aircraft carrier
Hiyō"), two destroyers, and one [tanker](/wiki/Tanker_\(ship\) "Tanker
\(ship\)") and damaged others. Two other carriers,
[_Taihō_](/wiki/Japanese_aircraft_carrier_Taih%C5%8D "Japanese aircraft
carrier Taihō") and [_Shōkaku_](/wiki/Japanese_aircraft_carrier_Sh%C5%8Dkaku
"Japanese aircraft carrier Shōkaku"), were sunk by submarines.

_Indianapolis_ returned to Saipan on 23 June, to resume fire support and six
days later moved to Tinian, to attack shore installations (see [Battle of
Tinian](/wiki/Battle_of_Tinian "Battle of Tinian")). Meanwhile, Guam had been
taken, and _Indianapolis_ was the first ship to enter [Apra
Harbor](/wiki/Apra_Harbor "Apra Harbor"), since early in the war. The ship
operated in the Marianas for the next few weeks, then moved to the Western
Carolines, where further landings were planned. From 12 to 29 September, she
bombarded [Peleliu](/wiki/Peleliu "Peleliu"), in the [Palau
Group](/wiki/Palau_Group "Palau Group"), before and after the landings (see
[Battle of Peleliu](/wiki/Battle_of_Peleliu "Battle of Peleliu")). She then
sailed to [Manus Island](/wiki/Manus_Island "Manus Island"), in the [Admiralty
Islands](/wiki/Admiralty_Islands "Admiralty Islands"), where she operated for
10 days before returning to the Mare Island Naval Shipyard in California for
refitting.

###
1945[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 1945")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(July 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
Overhauled, _Indianapolis_ joined VADM [Marc A.
Mitscher](/wiki/Marc_A._Mitscher "Marc A. Mitscher")'s fast carrier task force
on 14 February 1945. Two days later, the task force launched an attack on
Tokyo to cover the landings on Iwo Jima, scheduled for 19 February. This was
the first carrier attack on Japan since the [Doolittle
Raid](/wiki/Doolittle_Raid "Doolittle Raid"). The mission was to destroy
Japanese air facilities and other installations in the "[Home
Islands](/wiki/Japanese_archipelago "Japanese archipelago")". The fleet
achieved complete tactical surprise by approaching the Japanese coast under
cover of bad weather. The attacks were pressed home for two days. The US Navy
lost 49 carrier planes while claiming 499 enemy planes, a 10:1 kill/loss
ratio. The task force also sank a carrier, nine coastal ships, a destroyer,
two [destroyer escorts](/wiki/Destroyer_escort "Destroyer escort"), and a
cargo ship. They destroyed hangars, shops, aircraft installations, factories,
and other industrial targets.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_off_the_Mare_Island_Naval_Shipyard_on_10_July_1945_%2819-N-86911%29.jpg/300px-
USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_off_the_Mare_Island_Naval_Shipyard_on_10_July_1945_%2819-N-86911%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_off_the_Mare_Island_Naval_Shipyard_on_10_July_1945_\(19-N-86911\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_off_the_Mare_Island_Naval_Shipyard_on_10_July_1945_\(19-N-86911\).jpg
"Enlarge")

_Indianapolis_ off [Mare Island](/wiki/Mare_Island "Mare Island"), on 10 July
1945.

Immediately after the strikes, the task force raced to the Bonin Islands, to
support the [landings on Iwo Jima](/wiki/Battle_of_Iwo_Jima "Battle of Iwo
Jima"). The ship remained there until 1 March, protecting the invasion ships
and bombarding targets in support of the landings. _Indianapolis_ returned to
VADM Mitscher's task force in time to strike Tokyo, again on 25 February, and
[Hachijō](/wiki/Hachij%C5%8D,_Tokyo "Hachijō, Tokyo"), off the southern coast
of [Honshū](/wiki/Honsh%C5%AB "Honshū"), the following day. Although weather
was extremely bad, the American force destroyed 158 planes and sank five small
ships while pounding ground installations and destroying trains.

The next target for the US forces was [Okinawa](/wiki/Okinawa "Okinawa"), in
the [Ryukyu Islands](/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands "Ryukyu Islands"), which were in
range of aircraft from the Japanese mainland. The fast carrier force was
tasked with attacking airfields in southern Japan until they were incapable of
launching effective airborne opposition to the impending invasion. The fast
carrier force departed for Japan from Ulithi, on 14 March. On 18 March, it
launched an attack from a position 100 mi (160 km) southeast of the island of
[Kyūshū](/wiki/Ky%C5%ABsh%C5%AB "Kyūshū"). The attack targeted airfields on
Kyūshū, as well as ships of the Japanese fleet in the harbors of
[Kobe](/wiki/Kobe "Kobe") and [Kure](/wiki/Kure,_Hiroshima "Kure, Hiroshima"),
on southern Honshū. The Japanese located the American task force on 21 March,
sending 48 planes to attack the ships. Twenty-four
[fighters](/wiki/Fighter_aircraft "Fighter aircraft") from the task force
intercepted and shot down all the Japanese aircraft.

Pre-invasion bombardment of Okinawa began on 24 March. _Indianapolis_ spent 7
days pouring 8-inch shells into the beach defenses. During this time, enemy
aircraft repeatedly attacked the American ships. _Indianapolis_ shot down six
planes and damaged two others. On 31 March, the ship's lookouts spotted a
Japanese [Nakajima Ki-43](/wiki/Nakajima_Ki-43 "Nakajima Ki-43") "Oscar"
fighter as it emerged from the morning twilight and roared at the bridge in a
vertical dive. The ship's 20 mm guns opened fire, but within 15 seconds, the
plane was over the ship. Tracers converged on it, causing it to swerve, but
the enemy pilot managed to release his bomb from a height of 25 ft (7.6 m),
crashing his plane into the sea near the [port](/wiki/Port_\(nautical\) "Port
\(nautical\)") [stern](/wiki/Stern "Stern"). The bomb plummeted through the
deck, into the crew's [mess hall](/wiki/Mess_hall "Mess hall"), down through
the berthing compartment, and through the fuel tanks before crashing through
the keel and exploding in the water underneath. The concussion blew two gaping
holes in the keel which flooded nearby compartments, killing nine crewmen. The
ship's bulkheads prevented any progressive flooding. _Indianapolis_ , settling
slightly by the stern and listing to port, steamed to a salvage ship for
emergency repairs. Here, inspection revealed that her propeller shafts were
damaged, her fuel tanks ruptured, and her water-distilling equipment ruined.
But _Indianapolis_ commenced the long trip across the Pacific, under her own
power, to the [Mare Island Navy Yard](/wiki/Mare_Island_Navy_Yard "Mare Island
Navy Yard") for repairs.

## Secret
mission[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Secret mission")]

After major repairs and an overhaul, _Indianapolis_ received orders to proceed
to Tinian island, carrying parts and the [enriched
uranium](/wiki/Enriched_uranium "Enriched uranium")[14] (about half of the
world's supply of [Uranium-235](/wiki/Uranium-235 "Uranium-235") at the time)
for the atomic bomb _[Little Boy](/wiki/Little_Boy "Little Boy")_ , which
would later be dropped on [Hiroshima](/wiki/Hiroshima "Hiroshima").[15]
_Indianapolis_ departed San Francisco's [Hunters Point Naval
Shipyard](/wiki/Hunters_Point_Naval_Shipyard "Hunters Point Naval Shipyard")
on 16 July 1945, within hours of the [Trinity](/wiki/Trinity_\(nuclear_test\)
"Trinity \(nuclear test\)") test.

_Indianapolis_ set a speed record of ​74 1⁄2 hours[16] with an average speed
of 29 kn (54 km/h; 33 mph) from San Francisco to Pearl Harbor, which still
stands today. Arriving at Pearl Harbor on 19 July,[17] she raced on
unaccompanied,[18] delivering the atomic weapon components to Tinian on 26
July.[19]

_Indianapolis_ was then sent to Guam, where a number of the crew who had
completed their tours of duty were replaced by other sailors. Leaving Guam on
28 July, she began sailing toward [Leyte](/wiki/Leyte_\(island\) "Leyte
\(island\)"), where her crew was to receive training before continuing on to
Okinawa, to join VADM [Jesse B. Oldendorf](/wiki/Jesse_B._Oldendorf "Jesse B.
Oldendorf")'s Task Force 95.

###
Sinking[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Sinking")]

At 00:15 on 30 July, she was struck on her starboard side by two [Type 95
torpedoes](/wiki/Type_95_torpedo "Type 95 torpedo"), one in the bow and one
amidships, from the Japanese submarine [_I-58_](/wiki/Japanese_submarine_I-58
"Japanese submarine I-58"),[18] captained by
[Commander](/wiki/Naval_ranks_of_the_Japanese_Empire_during_World_War_II#Commissioned_officer_ranks
"Naval ranks of the Japanese Empire during World War II") [Mochitsura
Hashimoto](/wiki/Mochitsura_Hashimoto "Mochitsura Hashimoto"), who initially
thought he had spotted the [_New Mexico_ -class battleship](/wiki/New_Mexico-
class_battleship "New Mexico-class battleship")
[_Idaho_](/wiki/USS_Idaho_\(BB-42\) "USS Idaho \(BB-42\)").[20] The explosions
caused massive damage. _Indianapolis_ took on a heavy list, and settled by the
bow. Twelve minutes later, she rolled completely over, then her stern rose
into the air, and she plunged down. Some 300 of the 1,196 crewmen went down
with the ship. With few lifeboats and many without lifejackets, the remainder
of the crew was set adrift.[21]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/USS_Indianapolis-
last_voyage_chart.jpg/240px-USS_Indianapolis-
last_voyage_chart.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis-last_voyage_chart.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis-last_voyage_chart.jpg "Enlarge")

_Indianapolis_ 's intended route from Guam to the
[Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines").

###
Rescue[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Rescue")]

Navy command did not know about the ship's sinking until survivors were
spotted three and a half days later. At 10:25 on 2 August, a [PV-1
Ventura](/wiki/PV-1_Ventura "PV-1 Ventura") from [VPB-152](/wiki/VP-152
"VP-152") flown by [Lieutenant](/wiki/Lieutenant_\(navy\) "Lieutenant
\(navy\)") Wilbur "Chuck" Gwinn and copilot LT Warren Colwell spotted the men
adrift while on a routine patrol flight.[22] Gwinn immediately dropped a life
raft and a radio transmitter. All air and surface units capable of rescue
operations were dispatched to the scene at once.

[23] They suffered from lack of food and water (leading to
[dehydration](/wiki/Dehydration "Dehydration") and
[hypernatremia](/wiki/Hypernatremia "Hypernatremia"); some found
[rations](/wiki/Rations "Rations"), such as [Spam](/wiki/Spam_\(food\) "Spam
\(food\)") and [crackers](/wiki/Cracker_\(food\) "Cracker \(food\)"), amongst
the [debris](/wiki/Debris "Debris")), exposure to the elements (leading to
[hypothermia](/wiki/Hypothermia "Hypothermia") and severe
[desquamation](/wiki/Desquamation "Desquamation")), and [shark
attacks](/wiki/Shark_attack "Shark attack"), while some killed themselves or
other survivors in various states of [delirium](/wiki/Delirium "Delirium") and
[hallucinations](/wiki/Hallucinations "Hallucinations").[24][25]

"Ocean of Fear", a 2007 episode of the [Discovery
Channel](/wiki/Discovery_Channel "Discovery Channel") TV documentary series
_[Shark Week](/wiki/Shark_Week "Shark Week"),_ states that the sinking of
_Indianapolis_ resulted in the most shark attacks on humans in history, and
attributes the attacks to the [oceanic whitetip
shark](/wiki/Oceanic_whitetip_shark "Oceanic whitetip shark") species. [Tiger
sharks](/wiki/Tiger_shark "Tiger shark") might have also killed some sailors.
The same show attributed most of the deaths on _Indianapolis_ to exposure,
salt poisoning and [thirst](/wiki/Thirst "Thirst"), with the dead being
dragged off by sharks.[26]

### Navy failure to learn of the
sinking[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Navy failure to learn of the sinking")]

The Headquarters of Commander Marianas on Guam and of the Commander
[Philippine Sea Frontier](/wiki/Philippine_Sea_Frontier "Philippine Sea
Frontier") on Leyte, kept Operations plotting boards on which were plotted the
positions of all vessels with which the headquarters were concerned. However,
for ships as large as _Indianapolis,_ it was assumed that they would reach
their destinations on time, unless reported otherwise. Therefore, their
positions were based on predictions, and not on reports. On 31 July, when she
should have arrived at Leyte, _Indianapolis_ was removed from the board in the
headquarters of Commander Marianas. She was also recorded as having arrived at
Leyte by the headquarters of Commander Philippine Sea Frontier. LT Stuart B.
Gibson, the operations officer under the Port Director, Tacloban, was the
officer responsible for tracking the movements of _Indianapolis._ The vessel's
failure to arrive on schedule was known at once to LT Gibson, who failed to
investigate the matter and made no immediate report of the fact to his
superiors. Gibson received a letter of reprimand in connection with the
incident. The acting commander and operations officer of the Philippine Sea
Frontier also received reprimands, while Gibson's immediate superior received
a letter of admonition.[27]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/USS_Indianapolis-
survivors_on_Guam.jpg/300px-USS_Indianapolis-
survivors_on_Guam.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis-survivors_on_Guam.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis-survivors_on_Guam.jpg "Enlarge")

Survivors of _Indianapolis_ on Guam, in August 1945.

In the first official statement, the Navy said that distress calls "were keyed
by radio operators and possibly were actually transmitted" but that "no
evidence has been developed that any distress message from the ship was
received by any ship, aircraft or shore station".[27] Declassified records
later showed that three stations received the signals but none acted upon the
call. One commander was drunk, another had ordered his men not to disturb him
and a third thought it was a Japanese trap.[28]

Immediately prior to the attack, the seas had been moderate, the visibility
fluctuating but poor in general, and _Indianapolis_ had been steaming at 17 kn
(20 mph; 31 km/h). When the ship didn't reach Leyte on the 31st, as scheduled,
no report was made that she was overdue. This omission was due to a
misunderstanding of the [Movement Report System](/wiki/Movement_Report_System
"Movement Report System").

### Court-martial of Captain
McVay[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Court-martial of Captain McVay")]

Captain [Charles B. McVay III](/wiki/Charles_B._McVay_III "Charles B. McVay
III"), who had commanded _Indianapolis_ since November 1944, survived the
sinking and was among those rescued days later. In November 1945, he was
[court-martialed](/wiki/Court-martial "Court-martial") and convicted of
"hazarding his ship by failing to [zigzag](/wiki/Zigzag "Zigzag")". Several
things about the court-martial were controversial. There was evidence that the
Navy itself had placed the ship in harm's way, in that McVay's orders were to
"zigzag at his discretion, weather permitting". Further, Mochitsura Hashimoto,
commander of _I-58_ , testified that zigzagging would have made no
difference.[29] [Fleet Admiral](/wiki/Fleet_Admiral "Fleet Admiral") [Chester
Nimitz](/wiki/Chester_Nimitz "Chester Nimitz") remitted McVay's sentence and
restored him to active duty. McVay retired in 1949 as a [rear
admiral](/wiki/Rear_admiral_\(United_States\) "Rear admiral \(United
States\)").[30]

While many of _Indianapolis_ 's survivors said McVay was not to blame for the
sinking, the families of some of the men who died thought otherwise: "Merry
Christmas! Our family's holiday would be a lot merrier if you hadn't killed my
son", read one piece of mail.[31] The guilt that was placed on his shoulders
mounted until he [committed
suicide](/wiki/United_States_military_veteran_suicide "United States military
veteran suicide") in 1968, using his Navy-issued revolver. McVay was
discovered on his front lawn by his gardener with a toy sailor in one hand,
revolver in the other.[31][_[not in citation
given](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] He was 70
years old.

### McVay's record
cleared[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: McVay's record cleared")]

In 1996, sixth-grade student [Hunter Scott](/wiki/Hunter_Scott "Hunter Scott")
began his research on the sinking of _Indianapolis_ , which led to a United
States Congressional investigation. In October 2000, the [United States
Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") passed a
resolution that Captain McVay's record should state that "he is
[exonerated](/wiki/Exoneration "Exoneration") for the loss of _Indianapolis_
". [President Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") signed the
resolution.[32] The resolution noted that, although several hundred ships of
the US Navy were lost in combat in [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World
War II"), McVay was the only captain to be court-martialed for the sinking of
his ship.[33]

In July 2001, the United States Secretary of the Navy ordered McVay's official
Navy record cleared of all wrongdoing.[34][35]

## Discovery of the
wreck[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Discovery of the wreck")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/USS_Ohio_firing_detail.jpg/220px-
USS_Ohio_firing_detail.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Ohio_firing_detail.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Ohio_firing_detail.jpg "Enlarge")

Navy firing detail as part of a [burial-at-sea](/wiki/Burial-at-sea "Burial-
at-sea") in 2008 for one of the 317 survivors of _Indianapolis_ sinking on 30
July 1945.

The wreck of _Indianapolis_ is located in the Philippine Sea.[38] In
July–August 2001, an expedition sought to find the wreckage through the use of
[side-scan sonar](/wiki/Side-scan_sonar "Side-scan sonar") and underwater
cameras mounted on a [remotely operated
vehicle](/wiki/Remotely_operated_vehicle "Remotely operated vehicle"). Four
_Indianapolis_ survivors accompanied the expedition, which was not successful.
In June 2005, a second expedition was mounted to find the wreck. _[National
Geographic](/wiki/National_Geographic_\(magazine\) "National Geographic
\(magazine\)")_ covered the story and released it in July.
[Submersibles](/wiki/Submersible "Submersible") were launched to find any sign
of wreckage. The only objects ever found, which have not been confirmed to
have belonged to _Indianapolis_ , were numerous pieces of metal of varying
size found in the area of the reported sinking position (this was included in
the National Geographic program "Finding of the USS _Indianapolis_ ").

In July 2016, new information came out regarding the possible location of
_Indianapolis_ when naval records said that
[_LST-779_](/w/index.php?title=USS_LST-779&action=edit&redlink=1 "USS LST-779
\(page does not exist\)") passed by the ship 11 hours before the torpedoes
struck. Using this information, _National Geographic_ planned to mount an
expedition to search for the wreck in the summer of 2017.[39] Reports
estimated that _Indianapolis_ was actually 25 mi (40 km) west of the reported
sinking position, in water over three mi (4,800 m) deep, and likely on the
side of an underwater mountain.[40]

A year after the discovery of the records, the wreck was located by [Paul
Allen](/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen")’s "USS _Indianapolis_ Project" aboard
Research Vessel _Petrel_ [41] on 19 August 2017, at a depth of 18,000 feet
(5,500 m).[42] The wreck is well preserved due to the great depth at which
_Indianapolis_ rests, which is the rocky mountain ranges of the North
Philippine Sea.[43]

In September 2017, a map detailing the wreckage was released. The main part of
the wreck lies in an impact crater. Its bow, which broke off before the ship
sank, lies 1.5 miles (2.4 km) east. The two forward 8-inch guns, which also
broke off on the surface and mark the ship's last position on the surface, lie
0.5 miles (0.80 km) east of the main wreck. The single 8-inch gun turret on
the stern remains in place. Airplane wreckage from the ship lies about 0.6
miles (0.97 km) north of the main part of the wreck.[44]

##
Reunions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Reunions")]

Since 1960, surviving crew members have been meeting for reunions in
Indianapolis. For the 70th reunion, held 23–26 July 2015, 14 of the 32
remaining survivors attended. The reunions are open to anyone interested, and
have more attendees each year, even as the number of survivors decreases from
death. Held only periodically at first, biannually later on, the reunions have
been held annually for the past several years. Every year, the survivors, most
of them in their nineties, vote whether to continue.[45][46][47] Seven out of
twenty living survivors attended the 2017 reunion.[48]

## Popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Popular culture")]

References to the _Indianapolis_ sinking and aftermath have been adapted to
film, stage, television, and popular culture. The incident itself was the
subject of a 1991 [made-for-television](/wiki/Made-for-television "Made-for-
television") movie _Mission of the Shark: The Saga of the USS Indianapolis_ ,
with [Stacy Keach](/wiki/Stacy_Keach "Stacy Keach") portraying [Captain
Charles Butler McVay III](/wiki/Charles_Butler_McVay_III "Charles Butler McVay
III").

Probably the most well known fictional reference to the events occurs in the
1975 thriller film _[Jaws](/wiki/Jaws_\(film\) "Jaws \(film\)")_ in a
[monologue](/wiki/Monologue "Monologue") by actor [Robert
Shaw](/wiki/Robert_Shaw_\(British_actor\) "Robert Shaw \(British actor\)"),
whose character Quint is depicted as a survivor of the _Indianapolis_ sinking.
The monologue emphasizes the numerous deaths caused by shark attacks after the
sinking. [John Milius](/wiki/John_Milius "John Milius") was specifically
brought into the production to write lines for this scene and he based them on
survivor stories. However, there are several historical inaccuracies in the
monologue: The speech states the date of the sinking as 29 June 1945, when the
ship was actually sunk just after midnight on 30 July. The speech further
states that 1,100 men went into the water and 316 came out (321 came out, of
whom 317 survived) and that because of the secrecy of the atom bomb mission no
distress call was broadcast, while declassified Navy documents prove that the
signal had been sent but did not elicit a response.[49]

A few years after the release of _Jaws_ , co-writer [Howard
Sackler](/wiki/Howard_Sackler "Howard Sackler") proposed making a prequel film
based on the sinking of _Indianapolis_. The idea was ultimately rejected by
then-[Universal Studios](/wiki/Universal_Studios "Universal Studios")
president [Sidney Sheinberg](/wiki/Sidney_Sheinberg "Sidney Sheinberg"); the
film instead would eventually go on to become the sequel _[Jaws
2](/wiki/Jaws_2 "Jaws 2")_.[50]

Science fiction writer [Jack Chalker](/wiki/Jack_Chalker "Jack Chalker")'s
historical novel _[The Devil's Voyage](/wiki/The_Devil%27s_Voyage "The Devil's
Voyage")_ (1980) centers on the sinking of _Indianapolis_.

Sara Vladic directed _USS Indianapolis: The Legacy,_ which tells the fate of
USS _Indianapolis_ using exclusively first-person accounts from the survivors
of the sinking. This film was released in December 2015.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

_[USS Indianapolis: Men of Courage](/wiki/USS_Indianapolis:_Men_of_Courage
"USS Indianapolis: Men of Courage")_ , starring [Nicolas
Cage](/wiki/Nicolas_Cage "Nicolas Cage"), was released in October 2016, with
[Mario Van Peebles](/wiki/Mario_Van_Peebles "Mario Van Peebles")
directing.[51][52]

In _[The Burning Mountain](/wiki/The_Burning_Mountain "The Burning
Mountain"),_ an alternate history of the aborted invasion of Japan by [Alfred
Coppel](/wiki/Alfred_Coppel "Alfred Coppel"), USS _Bethlehem_ is based on the
secret mission and sinking of USS _Indianapolis._[53]

###
Memorials[[edit](/w/index.php?title=USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Memorials")]

See also: [U.S. Navy Museum § Other
museums](/wiki/U.S._Navy_Museum#Other_museums "U.S. Navy Museum")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_Memorial.jpg/220px-
USS_Indianapolis_%28CA-35%29_Memorial.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_Memorial.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)_Memorial.jpg "Enlarge")

USS _Indianapolis_ National Memorial

The USS _Indianapolis_ Museum had its grand opening on 7 July 2007, with its
gallery in the Indiana War Memorial Museum at the [Indiana World War Memorial
Plaza](/wiki/Indiana_World_War_Memorial_Plaza#Indiana_World_War_Memorial_Military_Museum
"Indiana World War Memorial Plaza").[54]

The USS _Indianapolis_ National Memorial was dedicated on 2 August 1995. It is
located on the [Canal Walk](/wiki/Indiana_Central_Canal "Indiana Central
Canal") in [Indianapolis](/wiki/Indianapolis "Indianapolis").[55] The heavy
cruiser is depicted in limestone and granite and sits adjacent to the downtown
canal. The crewmembers' names are listed on the monument, with special
notations for those who lost their lives.[56]

In May 2011, highway [I-465](/wiki/I-465 "I-465") around Indianapolis was
named the USS _Indianapolis_ Memorial Highway.[57]

Some material relating to _Indianapolis_ is held by the [Indiana State
Museum](/wiki/Indiana_State_Museum "Indiana State Museum"). Her
bell[_[dubious](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") –
[discuss](/wiki/Talk:USS_Indianapolis_\(CA-35\)#Pics_from_the_wreck_site_show_a_bell_on_the_sea_floor
"Talk:USS Indianapolis \(CA-35\)")_] and a commissioning pennant are located
at the [Heslar Naval Armory](/wiki/Heslar_Naval_Armory "Heslar Naval
Armory").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The swim training center at United States Navy Recruit Training Command is
named USS _Indianapolis_.
